thread.title: US holds on to win the Presidents Cup
thread.title_full: US holds on to win the Presidents Cup

author: DOUG FERGUSON
title: US holds on to win the Presidents Cup
text:
Lee Jin-man US holds on to win the Presidents Cup 
Rival captain's Jay Haas, left, of the US and Nick Price embrace after the United States team defeated the International team 15 1/2 to 14 1/2 to retain the Presidents Cup at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon, South Korea, Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015.(AP Photo/Lee Jin-man) Lee Jin-man US holds on to win the Presidents Cup 
United States' Chris Kirk, left, celebrates after sinking a putt on the 18th green to defeat International team player Anirban Lahiri of India 1up in their singles match at the Presidents Cup golf tournament at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon, South Korea, Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015.(AP Photo/Lee Jin-man) Lee Jin-man US holds on to win the Presidents Cup 
International team player Anirban Lahiri of India reacts on the 18th green after losing his match against United States' Chris Kirk in their singles match at the Presidents Cup golf tournament at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon, South Korea, Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015.(AP Photo/Lee Jin-man) Ahn Young-joon US holds on to win the Presidents Cup 
International team player Marc Leishman of Australia reacts after winning a hole during his singles match against United States' Jordan Spieth at the Presidents Cup golf tournament at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon, South Korea, Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015.(AP Photo/Ahn Young-joon) Lee Jin-man US holds on to win the Presidents Cup 
United States' Bubba Watson reacts after missing a putt on the 18th green during his singles match against International team player Thongchai Jaidee of Thailand at the Presidents Cup golf tournament at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon, South Korea, Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015.(AP Photo/Lee Jin-man) Lee Jin-man Presidents Cup, Capsules 
International team player Hedeki Matsuyama of Japan reacts after missing a putt on the 13th green during his singles match against United States' J.B. Holmes at the Presidents Cup golf tournament at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon, South Korea, Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015.(AP Photo/Lee Jin-man) Lee Jin-man US holds on to win the Presidents Cup 
International team player Danny Lee of New Zealand plays from a bunker on the 15th hole during his singles match against United States' Dustin Johnson at the Presidents Cup golf tournament at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon, South Korea, Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015.(AP Photo/Lee Jin-man) Woohae Cho US holds on to win the Presidents Cup 
United States' Phil Mickelson putts on the third green during his singles match against International team player Charl Schwartzel of South Africa at the Presidents Cup golf tournament at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon, South Korea, Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015.(AP Photo/Woohae Cho) Woohae Cho US holds on to win the Presidents Cup 
International team player Charl Schwartzel of South Africa reacts while putting on the third green during his singles match against United States' Phil Mickelson at the Presidents Cup golf tournament at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon, South Korea, Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015.(AP Photo/Woohae Cho) Ahn Young-joon US holds on to win the Presidents Cup 
United States' Jordan Spieth hits off the second tee during his singles match against International team player Marc Leishman of Australia at the Presidents Cup golf tournament at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon, South Korea, Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015.(AP Photo/Ahn Young-joon) US holds on to win the Presidents Cup Associated Press | 
INCHEON, South Korea (AP) — Bill Haas delivered the winning point to his team and to his father Sunday in a Presidents Cup that ended with a familiar result amid tension not felt in years. 
The Americans won for the sixth straight time, 15 1/2-14 1/2, only this was one came down to the final match. Subscription Required An online service is needed to view this article in its entirety.
